title: Simon Willison's LLM tool usage: 4,400 queries per day
description: Simon estimates his usage at 4,400 'typical queries' to an LLM per day, equivalent to around $15-$20 in daily costs. Demonstrates intensive usage patterns for AI coding assistance.
author: Simon Willison

title: Gas Town's agent patterns and design bottlenecks
description: Discussion about LLM-based coding orchestration and the limitations of AI-generated production-grade code. Explores the challenges of using AI for complex software engineering tasks.
author: Hacker News Community

title: Achieving 5x Agentic Coding Performance with Few-Shot Prompting
description: Towards Data Science article covering techniques for achieving 5x performance improvements in agentic coding through few-shot prompting strategies.
author: Towards Data Science

title: We're all VCs now: The skills developers need in the AI era
description: References Simon Willison's LLM predictions for 2026, predicting that within six years, humans writing code directly will be as outdated as using punch cards. Discusses the evolving skill requirements for developers.
author: Reuven Lerner

title: Why AI Keeps Falling for Prompt Injection Attacks
description: Bruce Schneier's blog notes Simon Willison's approach: wiping context clean if an LLM is on the wrong track rather than trying to correct it. Discusses persistent security vulnerabilities in AI systems.
author: Bruce Schneier (citing Simon Willison)

title: yolo-cage â€“ AI coding agents that can't exfiltrate secrets
description: A security-focused discussion about AI coding agents and the need to prevent secret exfiltration. The poster emphasizes that 'coding agents are power tools. They can be incredibly useful, but can also wreak a lot of havoc.'
author: Hacker News Community

title: Toward Automated and Trustworthy Scientific Analysis
description: ArXiv paper by AK Chakroborti exploring automated approaches to scientific analysis using AI, with focus on trustworthiness and verification of AI-generated insights.
author: AK Chakroborti

title: Does AI-Assisted Coding Deliver? A Comprehensive Study
description: ArXiv research paper by H. He et al. examining whether AI-assisted coding tools actually deliver on their promises, with empirical analysis of productivity gains and code quality.
author: H. He et al.

title: 10 things I learned from burning myself out with AI coding agents
description: Ars Technica article quoting Simon Willison on distinguishing serious AI-assisted development from casual 'vibe coding.' Discusses the importance of maintaining quality standards and the risks of over-reliance on AI tools.
author: Simon Willison (quoted)

title: Explanova: Automatically Discover Data Insights
description: A new ArXiv paper about automatically discovering data insights through 3 stages of analysis, representing advances in AI-powered data analysis and insight generation.
author: ArXiv Researchers

title: Using Local LLMs to Discover High-Performance Algorithms
description: Article from Towards Data Science discussing how to use local LLMs for discovering and optimizing high-performance algorithms, emphasizing cost-effective local deployment strategies.
author: Towards Data Science

title: COBOL developers: How are AI coding tools affecting your work?
description: Discussion asking COBOL/mainframe developers whether they see LLMs as a threat to job security or as helpful tools, exploring the impact of AI coding assistants on legacy systems maintenance.
author: Hacker News Community

title: The Code-Only Agent: Reusing previously generated code
description: A coding agent that reuses previously generated code, allowing tools to persist between sessions and helping the LLM avoid 'seeing' sensitive data. Discusses patterns for building more efficient and secure AI coding agents.
author: Hacker News Community

title: LLM Python library update with OpenAI model support
description: Simon released a new version of his LLM Python library and CLI tool for interacting with Large Language Models, including new OpenAI model support and improved features for developers.
author: Simon Willison
